comments.commentBody: Once Trump's numbers really started to panic him, his chaotic campaign Chiefs du jour seem to have persuaded him to zip it, read from their prompters, express nonsensical regrets, waver on his absurd deportation rants, and preposterously reach out to minorities that he has insulted all his working life.  The wager is that Americans are such complete idiots that they will forget everything he has said and stood for and believe that the Trump on the choke chain is real now.  the media will laud his new found presidential seriousness, since they need the to be a race that's closer than it is.

It's just about tomorrow on the east coast, but I wanted to chime in because we just completed a 10 day stay in Utah where we visited Zion and Bryce NPs, Cedar Breaks National Monument, and Utah State's Snow Canyon. I loved them all and went to see more. Loved the puzzle.
MTF, what can I say. You sound right and lost at the same time. But closer to right than lost.

no one knows if china has actually done that, stopped using organs of executed prisoners.  after all we are dealing with one of the least open and most closed of political systems, where dissidents are punished for "disturbing public order" and potentially threatening the state apparatus.
What a group of lunacy they represent.  He wants to be the head inmate running the asylum. What a delusional egotistical maniac he is. Where are his tax returns anyway?

What does the RNC care? They win if they have Hillary to pillory for four years. They win if Clinton does what they would have done for their corporate masters anyway. They win if she goes to war more. Why spend any RNC money on the presidential race at all?

Just from the description of his field operations, Trump is toast. Hillary has an extensive field operation in every state (I should know, I'm involved with two states, actually), a robust computer operation (ditto), and tons of identified volunteers waiting the call to help out (ditto again). And Trump has the old republican system—you know, the one famously crashing on election day 2012. The republicans have nothing, and their tiny field operation is not enough for GOTV or telephone canvassing. Sorry, Donald, but you don't have a prayer. So far as the whole republican party goes, I strongly suggest it start reading up on the history of the Whigs, from whence it came.

Even though the team won (again), I felt disappointed in their performance....it seemed as if they weren't really paying attention nor taking some of the more competitive games seriously....they were way off on their shooting during their last game.
Truth is, basketball is the least event I wanted to watch - it's like it's on all year round. Also, watching the pros is a bit boring: you know the outcome even before the jump ball.

Olympic basketball was very watchable compared with the NBA product. The shorter periods and European rules made for continuous action. And the last 5 minutes of the game did not take an hour.

The league superstars stayed home but the there were NBA players from many countries.

Now that's an endorsement. NBA basketball from November thru April is boring as heck. No defense played.

Saying the Olympic game is better isn't really saying much.

The Olympic game is lopsided with the current eligibility rules. Olympic Soccer's got it right - the young-ins plus two older guys.
Wow. What an underdog, feel good story.
Any truth to the rumor that Kevin Durant was thinking of emigrating to Serbia if the US team lost?
So they stayed in a lux cruise ship instead of interacting with players from other countries in the village. What is the purpose of their participation in the Olympics then?

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
This team appears to have really grown into their role of representing their country. Each U.S. squad has its story, and these men took the best the world had to offer.
Still no stories about the American woman who has taken gold in six CONSECUTIVE Olympics?
The United States won the men's Olympic basketball gold medal???!!!  YAWN.
Way to go sportsballers!

The author, Michael Powell wrote --"The Americans were hobbled throughout by the lack of a top-flight point guard. Chris Paul and Russell Westbrook, who have many rough N.B.A. miles on their personal odometers, opted to skip this Olympics." A list of NBA point guard talent that skipped the Olympics starts with Steph Curry.
Yes!  Now let's get back to business ... go Warriors!
This was Coach K's last hurrah.  Popovic is taking over the team, I believe next year, but definitely for the next Olympics.

If you actually followed USA Basketball, you'd know that Coach K will not be coaching the team in the future. The San Antonio Spurs' great coach, Gregg Popovich, will be heading the team through the next Olympic cycle.
Well, since this was Coach K's final Olympics, you need not ponder these questions again.

The USA basketball team in Rio had, by far, the most talent of any team in the competition -- even without LeBron James and Steph Curry. Yet, the team was not consistently dominant.

At the risk of committing heresy, it may be time to reconsider the accepted wisdom that Mike Krzyzewski is the only American coach worthy of leading an all-star cast in the Olympics.

The fact is that Coach K is a successful college recruiter with a built-in attraction of the Duke reputation, and he seems to be a very good teacher of basketball to youngsters just out of high school.

But, is that what is needed to coach the best NBA stars? Does Coach K fully appreciate the incredible skills and athletic talent of the best of the NBA?

If dominating the Olympic competition is a crass ambition, then the USOC should stay with Coach K and, perhaps, even require that the USA team roster include three present or recently graduated college players.
They are all professionals and were professionally paid even when still called "amateurs".

If the players were that concerned about money, they'd skip the Games altogether rather than risk an injury that could threaten their careers.

...but, yeah, let's get rid of the professionals. That would also entail abolishing all the government-run programs in most participating countries, and those most popular athletes in swimming and track, the Michael Phelps and Usain Bolts who profit from endorsements and prove the biggest draw to the Olympics, the bevy of athletes who earn prize money throughout year.

That'll go over... swimmingly.

In the past, our athletes were the only ones not making money while the IOC, and other national organizations were reaping a bonanza. And don't forget, it was the communist block nations who "ruined" the so-called amateurism in the Olympics by sending their professionals to compete against our amateurs. We finally got tired of losing and woke up to the fact that in order to have our best against their best, we needed to send the pros.
Allowing professionals to play in the Olympics devalues an already tainted extravaganza of money making wherein athletics is really an after thought.
More than 90% of all tickets were sold. Maybe folks didnt care much for some teams/sports. So, 100% in Brazil games in large venues, and 50% for US games, for instance...

I am going to miss the Olympics and Rio. They have much to be proud of. I love the joy of the Brazilian people. I love the green motif on the fonts and backgrounds. I think NBC did a good job, I especially enjoyed the streaming - I put in 8 hours on the wonderful rhythmic gymnastics - very classy and athletic. Bravo Rio - I learned from all of you.

A fine summary of a memorable Olympics. Shame on both Ryan Lochte and those overplaying that story when Phelps, Ledecky, Ervin and Manuel were making history and acting impeccably.

And bravo to King for calling out all the drug cheaters, even the American Justin Gatlin.

Congratulations Rio for everything except the booing of opponents such as the French pole vaulter who did nothing wrong.

This was a tremendous event, I´m sad it ended cause I had the time of life! Feel sorry for the gringos that didn´t come influenced by the international media that only talked about mosquitoes and tragedies. Hope those people have learned some lessons.

Ben, I have no idea either. I bought tickets when the Olympics had already started - just like many friends. In fact, many locals got excited with the Olympics after the opening ceremony and decided to buy tickets for sports events. However, when trying to purchase the cheapest tickets for some sports, they would appear as unavailable. On TV, many seats related to such tickets would be empty. I wonder if some VIP guests receive lots of tickets and simply don't go, because this situation is really strange.

As a carioca, born and raised in Rio, I wasn't excited for the Olympics. I feared the new subway line connecting the South Side of Rio to Barra da Tijuca - the suburb-like district of Rio where the Olympic Park is located - wouldn't be ready. I thought I was going to see the same lines for the Christ of the Redeemer and other attractions that I saw during the 2014 World Cup that were very disorganized.  I was also concerned about the huge expenditures on such event, especially with the press reporting that some of the projects had a much higher price tag than it had been previously announced, whereas teachers and police officers weren't receiving their salaries.  However, the 2016 Olympics were successful and it was nice to see so many cheerful people from all over the world visiting my city and learning more about Brazil. In the end, most things went well and the world could see its best athletes doing their job.

Macur's water metaphor & focus on fears and conflicts is all wet, washed up, kind of dippy. The events came off like clockwork, in well-crafted venues, uncompromised by the minor snafus which occur in all endeavours of this magnitude. And we saw spectaular performances!
To paraphrase a Paasover text, if I may: If I'd only seen the Final Five and not seen Kate Ledecky in the 800 m, it would have been enough for me..
If I'd seen Kate Ledecky,, and not seen Michael Phelps in free-style, it would have been enough for me...
If I'd just seen Anthony Earvin, it would have been enough for me..
If I'd seen Phelps, and not seen Kipchoge, it would have been enough...
If I'd seen Kipchoge and not seen Neymar's goal & kick, it would have been enough for me....

Dayenu. Great games!
Thank you, Brasil!  Thank you, Rio!
Every year I wonder why we don't hold the Olympics more often. What a joyous distraction!

So the games were not even close to the disaster many in the western media, including NYT, were predicting.  Good for Brazil, 2nd emerging nation to host this mega event after China in '08, and none of the performers had to wear diapers during rehearsals.
